case_title: K. RAMA MOHAN RAO and 2 others vs COMMISSIONER OF INCOME-TAX
reference_no_or_id: Income-tax Cases Nos.46 of 1995, 2 of 1996 and 23 of 1999
case_number: Income-tax Cases Nos.46 of 1995, 2 of 1996 and 23 of 1999

accussed_details.name: K. RAMA MOHAN RAO
allegation: Improper deduction claims under Income Tax Act, 1961

complaint_summary: The appellants sought reference of legal questions arising from the Tribunal's orders regarding disallowed interest deductions claimed under sections 57 and 67 of the Income Tax Act, 1961.
investigation_summary: The Tribunal found that the borrowings were used to liquidate debit balances in the firm's accounts and were not directly related to the acquisition of shares in SEW Constructions (P.) Limited.
judgment_summary: The High Court agreed with the Tribunal that no question of law arose for consideration. The applications were dismissed as the Tribunal's findings were based on factual appreciation and did not warrant legal intervention.
legal_arguments: The borrowed money was used to liquidate liabilities in the firm's accounts, not for acquiring shares.
The interest claimed could not be allowed under sections 57 or 67 of the Income Tax Act, 1961.
The Tribunal distinguished the Supreme Court's decision in CIT v. Rajendra Prasad Moody (1978) 115 ITR 519.
assets: Shares allotted in SEW Constructions (P.) Limited
citations: CIT v. Rajendra Prasad Moody (1978) 115 ITR 519
key_issues: Whether interest claimed by the assessee could be allowed as deduction under sections 57 and 67.
Whether borrowed money had a nexus to the acquisition of shares in SEW Constructions (P.) Limited.
Whether the borrowed amounts were used to discharge liabilities in the firm's accounts.
key_questions: Whether the interest claimed by the assessee could be allowed as deduction?
Whether the borrowed money invested had any nexus to the allotment of shares by the private limited company?
Whether the borrowed amounts deposited in the firm were in discharge of the assessee's liability?

tribunal_findings.borrowings_purpose: Liquidation of outstanding debit balance against partners in the firm's account
tribunal_findings.nexus_with_shares: No nexus established between borrowings and acquisition of shares
tribunal_findings.deduction_disallowed: Interest claimed could not be allowed under sections 57 or 67

facts.debit_balance_example: Rs.2,90,169 for K. Ramamohan Rao as of April 1, 1980
facts.borrowed_amount_example: Rs.2,99,000 deposited by K. Ramamohan Rao

tribunal_reasoning.income_relation: Interest incurred was not relatable to income earned during the relevant assessment years
tribunal_reasoning.investment_purpose: Amounts were utilised to discharge partners' liability, not for acquisition of shares
tribunal_reasoning.precedent_distinction: Supreme Court decision in CIT v. Rajendra Prasad Moody distinguished due to lack of direct investment in shares

high_court_observation.question_of_law: No question of law arises for consideration
high_court_observation.tribunal_approach: Tribunal approached the issue correctly based on facts and record

legal_terms.Nexus: Connection or link between two entities.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around disallowed interest deductions claimed by the appellants under the Income Tax Act, 1961. The Tribunal and High Court found no legal questions arising from the facts, as the borrowings were used to settle liabilities rather than acquire shares directly.
